ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about how comparative literature courses are structured at Yale, and gained writing and close reading skills.
I have developed my writing skills as well as my close reading abilities
I read a lot, and got to know how students from other parts of the world, especially the US, respond to the texts.

I learned so much about close-reading (by trial and error), how to be clear in writing, how to approach a single, specific topic from so many angles. I also spoke way more in this class than I ever have before due to the positive and welcoming environment. It has drastically helped me develop my ability to contribute to conversation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths  well-chosen book list, interesting overlaps between books. Relevant historical context brought in by professor. Some fun close reading group projects in the first parts of the course.

Weaknesses  super rushed at the end, just as a result of how short YSS is. Pacing overall wasn't great. Too much time spent in discussion which made it really obvious when some people hadn't done the reading.
I think that the course could spend a little more time in breakout rooms, and have breakout room time be a bit more organized with tasks.

The strengths were the incredible instructing, the interesting and diverse material, and the inspiration I received from other students. The only weakness I can think of is maybe the high volume of reading, which led me to have to skim some things that I would have preferred to read more closely, but it didn't reduce the value of the class to me at all, and was mostly a scheduling issue on my part.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but definitely during a regular semester because the pace of summer session lowkey forced me to skim readings otherwise I wouldn't have finished them.
Yes, as a way to read interesting books and gain an introduction to comparative literature. Probably not nearly as rewarding as humanities classes taken during the academic year, though.
I would. I think it opened me up to a lot of literature I otherwise would not have explored and I enjoyed discussing the books in class.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student. This is one of the best classes I have taken at Yale, and I really believe that, no matter what subject a student is studying, this material would be interesting to anyone.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.

extras.title: LITR S318 01 - The Problem of Evil
